The Cabinet bad before them a Memorandum bythe Secretary of State fur Dominion Affairs (paper c.P.-316 (29)) in regard to the progress of theConference on the Operation of Dominion Legislation^asking for decisions from the Cabinet In regard tothe following points:-(i) The sanction to be given to theagreement reached at the Conferenceon the subject of legislation withregard to the crown,"and certain aspects of Defence legislation:(ii) As to the line he and the Attorney-General should take in regard tothe provisions necessary to safe-guard the position of DominionConstitutions.The Attorney-General explained to the Cabinetin considerable detail the precise issues Which had arisen. The first point was as to the method bywhich the position of the Crown was to be safeguarded.The Governments Delegates wished to know whetherthey were justified in resting content with anagreement with the Dominions that no member of theBritish Commonwealth of Nations would try and alter the position of the Crown without the consent of allother parts, including, of oourse, the United Kingdom,or, alternatively, were they to insist on themaintenance of the existing British Statute which theDominions regarded as inconsistent with equality ofstatus.In this connection attention was drawn to the precise terms of the formula regarding equality ofstatus agreed to at the Imperial Conference, 1926,as well as to the formula which the Cabinet at a ;;previous Meeting (Cabinet 39 (29), Conclusion 2(e))had suggested that the Delegates should adopt inorder to preserve freedom of the Government at the Imperial Conference.The second point on which the Attorney-Generalasked for instructions was as to how to deal withthe difficulty that had arisen in regard to theamendment of the Constitutions of the Dominions.Three of the Dominions wished
